author: @todonoticias
title: Cande Tinelli detalló el momento en el que se dio cuenta que debía separarse de Coti Sorokin | TN
text:
Cande Tinelli se distanció de Coti Sorokin a un año de haberse casado . La noticia generó un fuerte impacto en las redes sociales, y el revuelo hizo que la joven saliera a hablar para aclarar qué fue lo que les pasó. Con total sinceridad, aseguró que tenían muchos desencuentros.
“Veníamos mal, muy mal . Estamos viendo cómo seguir ”, expresó en El Diario de Mariana (América). Acto seguido, lanzó una frase que expuso el momento en el que decidió separarse del popular intérprete: “ Dejé todo por él y me olvidé de mí, ja. Pero nada es suficiente a veces . Soy fuerte, voy a estar bien”.
Leé también: Una tarotista ventiló cómo hizo la China Suárez para conquistar a Mauro Icardi y desató un escándalo
Por último, remarcó en que se encuentra “reencontrándose”. Mientras que él regresó a Buenos Aires en soledad, ella optó por quedarse con su familia en Punta del Este, uno de sus lugares favoritos. Por ahora, no hay ninguna esperanza de reconciliación.
Cande Tinelli y Coti Sorokin, otra vez separados. (Foto: instagram/candelariatinelli) Otro disgusto para Marcelo Tinelli: su hijo Francisco volcó en Punta del Este Francisco Tinelli protagonizó un accidente durante la madrugada del miércoles cuando evadió a una patrulla de la policía mientras circulaba a alta velocidad por Punta del Este. Según el informe realizado por las autoridades de Maldonado, el joven terminó perdiendo el control de su camioneta, se accidentó y cuando le hicieron el test de alcoholemia, dio positivo.
Al aire de TN , Marcelo Umpierrez , periodista del Canal 4- AIL- , dio detalles sobre lo ocurrido y expuso el pedido que le habría hecho Francisco a los oficiales que lo demoraron. “ Después de lo ocurrido, le pidió a uno de los efectivos policiales si podía conseguirle cigarrillos y ellos se los dieron” , detalló el cronista.
Francisco Tinelli, en problemas. (Foto: Revista ¡Hola!) “Después de que el médico revisa que esté todo bien y lo ven en condiciones, le dan el alta para ser trasladado por los propios efectivos policiales a la dependencia de seccional 12 en La Barra para hacer el test de alcoholemia y ver el resto de las contravenciones que podrían caber allí ”, comentó Umpierrez.
Sobre el procedimiento, sumó: “Se hizo el control de alcoholemia, como se hace ante cualquier tipo de siniestro, que le da 0.27. Tenía un mínimo por encima del 0 y ahí tiene una contravención, pero no ingresó dentro de la Ley de Faltas. Es una multa simple. Lo mismo aplica por la alta velocidad”.

author: choliday@newscenter1.com (Christina Holiday)
title: Four tips from Black Hills Energy to help winterize your home before the cold rushes in
text:
RAPID CITY, S.D.– While we have been lucky in Rapid City and the greater Black Hills region to have had such pleasant and mild temperatures from fall through the first couple of days of 2024, the cold is preparing to come back once more.
To help make sure your home stays warm while saving on the monthly bill, General Manager of Operations for Black Hills Energy Michael Pogany shares a few tips to keep in mind.
Check your thermostat
As Pogany says, checking your thermostat and having it set to an appropriate temperature ranks among the first things to do for any homeowner or renter. As for what an appropriate setting is, Black Hills Energy recommends setting the temperature to 68 degrees and lowering it a little before going to bed. "Also, if you have a programable or smart thermostat, that's an opportunity to lower those temperatures when you're not around and then also increase the temperatures when you are home to stay more comfortable." He also adds that if the function is available, turn on the fan in your home to help with air circulation and keep the temperature in the home more consistent.
Replace and refill
Whether for cleaning purposes or energy efficiency, do not forget to change your furnace filters regularly for maximum operation potential. However, make sure to check with the packaging on how often filters need replacing. Oftentimes, many will range anywhere from one to three months.
In the home, regardless of the type of dwelling, Pogany adds that around 10 percent of energy loss takes place due to issues with windows and doors. "And so if you have gaps and cracks in your windows and doors, fill them with weather stripping or caulking to make sure that you keep the heat in and the cool out."
Tips for winterizing your home, courtesy of Black Hills Energy
Furnace filters should be replaced every one to three monthsUpdated
Only clear meters of snow, ice, or any other materials by handUpdated
Adjudt your thermostat to an efficient settingUpdated
Make sure to check and replace air filters regularlyUpdated
Check the pipes and meters around the outside of your homeUpdated
Be sure to make sure any vents, pipes, and ,eters are clear and cleaned of any materialsUpdated
A smart thermostat can help with temperature regulation while you are in and out of the homeUpdated
Check around the house
After the snow falls and the ice sets in, he also says it is important to take a lap around the house outside and check any pipes, meters, or vents associated with the heating and cooling devices to make sure they are clear. And if they have any fallen material on them, clear them by hand only. "Some of those devices are sensitive and could be broken by using a shovel," he explained. "And so we just encourage you to take a walk around, take a look at your vents and pipes, make sure that they're clear and open to ensure that your furnaces and your heat pumps operate properly during the winter. "
Insulation
While caulking and weather strips are one way of keeping heat inside, insulation is also just as important. In Rapid City cold weather often comes from the northwest, Pogany explains. Checking exterior walls on the north and west-facing sides of homes for proper insulation can also help keep the heat inside.
And if you have an attic, make sure to check up there as well. "open that up and make sure that you have proper insulation in the attic. That can make a big difference because heat rises and you can actually lose the heat you're generating in your house."
For more tips on winterizing your home from Black Hills Energy, check their
website.

organizations.name: general manager of operations for black hills energy michael pogany

author: Archangel Nzangaya
title: Concerned NONM members threaten to shut down offices
text:
A group of over 3500 paid-up members of the National Organization of Nurses and Midwives (NONM) in Malawi are threatening to shut down the organization’s offices due to the leadership’s failure to secure a lucrative deal with the government on allowance adjustment.
The members, led by Frank Kamwendo, a prominent nurse who played a key role in lobbying for the mass recruitment of nurses and midwives from 2023 to 2024, are demanding answers from the NONM leadership.
Kamwendo revealed that NONM members had expected the 2025-2026 budget to reflect the agreed-upon adjustments to specific allowances for health workers, as the relevant ministries had already signed off on the deal. Instead, the budget’s omission of these allowances has sparked outrage and disappointment among NONM members.
He then expressed disappointment, stating that the NONM leadership has failed miserably in securing the deal, despite having a “listening government” that is willing to work with the organization.
“Many nurses are wallowing in poverty and we cannot continue like this. The leadership should, therefore, provide tangible answers as to why they have failed miserably on a dead rubber deal,” said Kamwendo.
The concerned members have warned that they will take drastic action, including closing down NONM offices if the leadership fails to provide tangible explanations for their failure to secure the deal.
Kamwendo emphasized that the members will no longer condone such gross incompetence, stating that “sleeping on duty cannot be condoned.”

organizations.name: the National Organization of Nurses and Midwives

author: El Correo
title: 2024, otro año «muy cálido» en el que Bilbao alcanzó los 44 grados
text:
Secciones
Servicios
Destacamos
El Correo
Viernes, 3 de enero 2025, 00:52
Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad.
En materia meteorológica ya nada es normal. Así que 2024 tampoco lo fue. Ha hecho más calor del que cabría prever según las series históricas y también ha llovido más de lo habitual. De hecho esto, lo excepcional, parece ser la nueva normalidad. Un efecto conocido y anunciado del cambio climático.
«Hace años que no tenemos un año meteorológico normal», asumió ayer Margarita Martín, delegada de la Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (Aemet) en el País Vasco. El que acaba de terminar ha dejado unas temperaturas medias que han estado un 1,1 grados por encima de lo habitual; eso sí, el desvío, siendo notable, ha sido menos estridente que en los dos años anteriores, que fueron aún más cálidos. De hecho, fueron los más calurosos desde 1927. Por su parte, 2024 ocupa la décima posición en ese ranking histórico, apuntó Martín durante una entrevista en Radio Bilbao.
Puede que uno de los episodios más llamativos en este sentido fuese el ocurrido el 11 de agosto, jornada especialmente tórrida que, dijo la meteoróloga, dejó 44 grados en Bilbao. Eso sí, matizó que esa cifra había sido arrojada en una estación automática. Porque según los datos oficiales, esa temperatura se alcanzó, e incluso superó, en Sodupe, mientras que la capital habría rozado los 42. En cualquier caso, no estaríamos ante un registro histórico, como sí sucedió en Hondarribia con sus 40,7 grados.
También ha llovido más de lo que se considera normal. En concreto, las precipitaciones han superado en un 20% la media histórica tanto en Bizkaia como en Gipuzkoa. Recordó la responsable de la Aemet que en agosto hubo episodios de dana que dejaron lluvias torrenciales, pero no de carácter extraordinario en ningún caso comparables con los «250 litros en un día» que se alcanzaron en agosto de 1983 y que terminaron provocando las fatales inundaciones.
Este cambio en la climatología forma parte de un guión conocido desde hace décadas como efecto del calentamiento global. Lo que sí está sorprendiendo es la velocidad a la que se está produciendo el ascenso de las temperaturas, que década tras década empeora los peores escenarios que se van pronosticando en las cumbres climáticas.
Para hoy se espera una ligera bajada de las temperaturas y también habrá lluvias. Y mañana, con la llegada del viento sur, se prevé que los termómetros ganen altura. Para después de Reyes, según el pronóstico de Margarita Martín, regresará el frío y las precipitaciones.

Publicidad
Publicidad

author: Brandon Canevari, Brattleboro Reformer
title: Year in Review: Brayden Eastman scores 1,000th career point | Sports | reformer.com
text:
Hinsdale’s Brayden Eastman embraces members of his family after scoring his 1,000th career point against Franklin on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023.
Reformer file photo HINSDALE, N.H. — In the Hinsdale boys basketball team’s second game of the season against Franklin, the Pacers' Brayden Eastman scored his 1,000th career point, placing him alongside a select group of people in the school’s history. The rarity of Eastman’s accomplishment makes it the Reformer’s No. 4 sports story of the year.
Eastman began the season 52 points away from the milestone. After he dropped 34 points on Sunapee in the season opener, helping lead Hinsdale to a convincing 71-42 win, he was just 18 points shy, setting the stage for him to accomplish the feat against Franklin in the team’s home opener.
With 2:42 remaining in the game against Franklin, Eastman surpassed the 1,000-point mark off a beautiful alley-oop pass in transition from Connor Dixon to put the Pacers up 54-44 on their way to a 58-46 win.
“I’m definitely glad it was from one of my teammates instead of me creating a bucket for myself because people scoring 1,000 points isn’t just them, it’s the team around them that’s really, truly, the reason why they scored that 1,000 points,” said Eastman after the game.
In scoring the bucket, Eastman achieved a milestone that a limited number of basketball players in Hinsdale history ever have. The last player in the school’s history to score 1,000 points was Angelina Nardolillo in 2019, and Matt Boggio was the last member of the boys team to reach 1,000 points in 2016.
Hinsdale’s Brayden Eastman drives through Franklin’s defense during a boys basketball game on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023.
Reformer file photo Coach Carl Anderson said he had drawn up a similar play during a pause in play, but the team was unable to execute it at that time.
“They (Franklin) had come out in the zone and then for that to happen on a fast break was even better,” Anderson said.
Hinsdale (2-0) never trailed in the game. They started the game with an 11-1 run and held a 16-7 lead after the first quarter, eight of which came from Eastman, though he was double teamed on more than one instance at the beginning of the game.
“It was definitely getting in my head,” said Eastman of the milestone. “I was struggling throughout the beginning, but the AD (Athletic Director Sam Kilelee) said to me ‘Just keep going. Don’t worry about it. Just keep doing what you’re doing.’ I always listen to him. He’s always got good advice.”
Eastman and Dixon combined for 37 of the team’s points on the evening to help earn the win.
Throughout the game, Eastman, who finished with 22 points, played within the offense, giving the ball up to teammates frequently to ensure that Hinsdale maintained the lead.

author: a cura della redazione Cronaca
title: “Babbo Natale non esiste”. Nuovo caso in una scuola elementare in provincia di Vicenza. La protesta dei genitori. La direttrice: “Tutto un equivoco”
text:
Babbo Natale esiste o no? Per i bambini (ancora) sì ma c’è chi spesso se ne dimentica, infrangendo quei pochi sogni che sono rimasti ai più piccoli. Stavolta la polemica su Babbo Natale stavolta è scoppiata in una scuola del Veneto, un istituto paritario di ispirazione cattolica.
Come riporta il Giornale di Vicenza , nel discorso prenatalizio la direttrice si è fatta sfuggire davanti ad alcuni bambini il fatto che Babbo Natale non esiste.
L'episodio si è verificato alla scuola "San Giuseppe" di Torri di Quartesolo (Vicenza), durante le recite di Natale dei bimbi delle elementari. La dirigente, Milena Meggiorin , parlando di aiuto al prossimo, pace, fantasia e sogni, ha citato quanto avvenuto in una scuola primaria di Firenze , in cui era stato detto esplicitamente ai bimbi che il vecchio con la barba che porta i regali non esiste, sottolineando che comunque arriverà il momento della scoperta da parte dei bambini. Ma questa osservazione è stata colta da alcuni degli alunni presenti insieme alle famiglie, che hanno iniziato anche a piangere, sollevando le proteste dei genitori.
Meggiorin si è scusata affermando che si è trattato di un fraintendimento, e di essersi espressa anche in base alle indicazioni dell'ufficio scolastico che aveva citato l'episodio di Firenze, ma di avere avuto l'intenzione di ribadire l'importanza del "pensiero magico" nei bimbi.

author: Avery Davidson
title: Sen. John Kennedy Co-sponsors Bill to Address Federal Government Overreach on Farmers, Ranchers and Landowners
text:
Rounds Leads Legislation to Address Federal Government Overreach on South Dakota Farmers, Ranchers and Landowners
WASHINGTON – U.S. Senator Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) today reintroduced legislation to address federal government overreach and provide regulatory certainty to South Dakota farmers, ranchers and landowners. The Farmers Freedom Act of 2025 would provide a permanent definition of prior converted cropland (PCC) under the Clean Water Act. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has used this authority to issue Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rulemakings, which regulates navigable waterways in the United States.
For the last several decades, wetlands converted to cropland before 1985 have remained exempt from WOTUS regulation. Under the Biden administration ruling, previously-converted cropland could revert to a wetland status if it becomes unavailable for commodity production due to circumstances like flooding. This causes land to be subject to federal regulation regardless of a previous exemption. To prevent this from happening, Rounds’ legislation would amend the Clean Water Act to allow PCC land to be farmed only once every five years to remain exempt from being regulated under WOTUS.
“South Dakota farmers and ranchers work hard to protect their land, and they don’t need a heavy-handed federal government subjecting them to additional burdensome rule changes,” said Rounds. “While past administrations have issued problematic WOTUS rules, the previous Navigable Waters Protection Rule under the first Trump administration worked to protect owners of prior converted cropland from undue regulation while providing producers with needed flexibility. This legislation seeks to make this definition of PCC permanent, preventing overreach and giving landowners the freedom to use their land how they see fit.”
The Farmers Freedom Act of 2025 is cosponsored by Majority Leader John Thune (R-S.D.) and Senators John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), John Hoeven (R-N.D.) and Roger Marshall (R-Kan.).
This legislation is endorsed by the South Dakota Farm Bureau and the American Farm Bureau.
“Unfortunately, the definition of prior converted cropland (PCC) in the latest WOTUS regulations will only contribute to further uncertainty for producers,” said Scott VanderWal, President of the South Dakota Farm Bureau. “I thank Senator Rounds for introducing legislation to provide flexibility for farmers across South Dakota.”
“Farmers take seriously the responsibility for properly caring for the land they’ve been entrusted with,” said Courtney Briggs, American Farm Bureau’s Senior Director of Government Affairs. “The current rules surrounding prior converted cropland make it difficult for farmers to ensure they are making the best use of their land while protecting the environment. We appreciate Sen. Rounds for working to bring clarity to the PCC exclusion.”
BACKGROUND:
- For the last several decades, wetlands that were drained to be cropland prior to 1985 have remained exempt from regulation under the Clean Water Act.
- In 2015, the Obama administration finalized a rule that expanded the definition of WOTUS, creating confusion and burdensome red tape, especially for South Dakota’s agricultural communities.
- The Trump administration released a proposed rule to replace the 2015 WOTUS rule with a new one that provided much-needed certainty for farmers by establishing clear and reasonable definitions of what qualifies as a “water of the United States.” The Navigable Waters Protection Rule (NWPR) was finalized in 2020.
- The NWPR clarified the rules governing PCC, protecting impacted land from Clean Water Act regulation as long it was used for agricultural purposes once every five years.
- On day one of his administration, President Biden signed an executive order to begin the process of rolling back the Trump administration’s NWPR.
- In December 2022, the EPA issued a new rule repealing the NWPR and changing the definition of WOTUS in a way that will expand federal regulatory authority.
- The Biden administration’s WOTUS rule also tightened the regulations guiding PCC, allowing the federal government to end the exemption for such land immediately upon a change in use.
- In May 2023, the Supreme Court issued a decision in Sackett v. Environmental Protection Agency that overturned the previous 2022 WOTUS rule.
- In August 2023, the EPA issued a new iteration of the WOTUS rule with changes after Sackett, which retained the problematic definition of PCC.
Click HERE to read full bill text.
###
